senses.de: To deliberately stay away from something or keep from doing something
senses.ex: She keeps avoiding me every time I try to speak to her.

Tips.title: Social Avoidance
Tips.description: Used when someone intentionally avoids social interaction with a person or group.
Tips.example: Jim has been avoiding Sarah since their argument.

Tips.title: Deliberate Action
Tips.description: Emphasizes the act is intentional, not accidental.
Tips.example: She isn't just busy; she's avoiding meeting with you.

Tips.title: Negative Context
Tips.description: Often has a negative connotation, as it implies evasion or reluctance.
Tips.example: Avoiding responsibilities will lead to more problems.

senses.ex: Eating healthy can help avoid diseases.

Tips.title: Preventive Measure
Tips.description: Implies taking steps to prevent undesired outcomes or consequences.
Tips.example: By studying regularly, you can avoid failing the exam.

Tips.title: Safety and Caution
Tips.description: Often used in contexts related to safety, caution, and health.
Tips.example: Wear a helmet to avoid head injuries while cycling.

Tips.title: Problem-Solving
Tips.description: Carries the idea of being proactive to sidestep potential issues.
Tips.example: Avoid problems with your computer by backing up your data.

senses.de: In law, to make something void
senses.ex: The contract was avoided due to the fraudulent acts of one party.

Tips.title: Legal Specificity
Tips.description: Used in legal terms to indicate voiding or annulling agreements or conditions.
Tips.example: The judge ruled to avoid the agreement as it was signed under duress.

Tips.title: Legal Action
Tips.description: Suggests a formal action taken to refute or cancel a legal commitment.
Tips.example: You can avoid the penalty if you prove there was a misunderstanding.

Circumvent.wordDefinition:
Circumvent means to find a way to get around or bypass something. For example, if there is a traffic jam on the highway, you might try to circumvent it by taking a back road.

The main difference between these words is that avoid is used to prevent something from happening, while circumvent is used when you need to find a way to get around something that is in your way.

Dodge.wordDefinition:
Avoid means to keep away from something or not engage in it, while dodge means to move quickly aside or out of the way to avoid something.

If you're playing dodgeball and someone throws a ball at you, you might dodge the ball by quickly moving out of the way so it doesn't hit you.

Avoid is used when you want to prevent or steer clear of something, while dodge is used when you need to quickly react and move to avoid something that is coming towards you.

Elude.wordDefinition:
Elude means to escape or evade something or someone, especially by being very clever or skillful. For example, if you're playing tag and you run so fast and change direction so quickly that the person chasing you cannot catch you, you elude them.

Avoid is to intentionally stop doing something, while elude is to unintentionally escape from something.

Escape.wordDefinition: Escape means to leave a situation or place that is dangerous, difficult, or uncomfortable. It is applicable when you are in a situation that you need to get away from quickly or when you want to leave a place where you feel trapped or uncomfortable.

Eschew.wordDefinition:
Avoid and eschew both refer to steering clear of something, but they have different nuances.

Eschew implies that you are consciously rejecting and avoiding something that you believe is morally or ethically wrong.

For example, you might eschew buying products made using child labour because you believe it is wrong to support such practices.

To put it simply, avoid means to stay away from something because you don't want to deal with it, while eschew means to avoid something because you believe it is wrong.

Evade.wordDefinition:
Avoid and evade have similar meanings, but there is a slight difference in usage. Avoid means to intentionally stay away from something or someone in order to stay safe or prevent a negative outcome.

Evade means to avoid or escape something or someone by being clever or deceptive. It often implies that someone is actively trying to catch or harm you, and you are trying to avoid them or their actions.

For example, a burglar might try to evade the police by hiding or taking a different route, or a politician might evade questions from journalists by changing the subject or giving vague answers.

Avoid is generally used in a more straightforward and direct sense, while evade has a connotation of being sneaky or deceptive.

Shun.wordDefinition:
Shun means to deliberately avoid, ignore or reject (someone or something) often due to disapproval or dislike.

Avoid means to stay away from something, while shun means to actively reject or ignore something or someone.

Sidestep.wordDefinition:
Both ‘avoid’ and ‘sidestep’ mean not to confront something directly, but ‘avoid’ typically means to stay away from something or someone to prevent harm or negative consequences, while ‘sidestep’ means to avoid something by taking an indirect or evasive action.

However, if someone asks a question that you do not want to answer, you might sidestep the issue by changing the subject or not answering directly.
